Award.AwardTitle: SCC-Planning: Using Innovations in Big Data and Technology to Address the High Rate of Infant Mortality in Greater Columbus Ohio

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Franklin County, Ohio, home of the state's capital at Columbus, has one of the highest infant mortality rates in the country at 8.3 deaths per 1,000 live births. As outlined in a recent article in the Journal of the American Medical Association (2016), the U.S. lags behind in many important measures of population health, including infant mortality, despite the fact that one-fifth of our dollars are spent on healthcare. While the data needed to address these important public health problems are available, to date we have not seen adequate investment in informatics approaches to combine and analyze these multilevel (e.g., individual lifestyle factors, neighborhood characteristics) data. The current planning project represents an effort to plan (with an intent to implement) just such an approach to address the high rate of infant mortality in Greater Columbus and nationwide. As the recent winner of the Department of Transportation's Smart Cities Challenge, Columbus already has a well-developed plan to employ technology to improve local transportation options, which is anticipated to ameliorate some contributing factors such as lack of access prenatal and other health care. The financial support from this and follow-up grants will permit us to expand that effort and leverage technological advances to further identify and design interventions to address risk factors for poor maternal and infant health outcomes. Further, by including students and other trainees in our work, we will be training the next generation of scientists to develop innovative solutions to address complex societal problems.

The objectives of this one-year planning project are to: 1) identify data gaps that present local barriers to achieving optimal maternal and infant health and their effect on proximate causes of infant mortality in the community; 2) align with key stakeholders and partners in the community with a goal to identify opportunities where technology, especially connectivity and mobility, could be leveraged to address barriers and speed-up progress; and 3) utilize our technological and content expertise to design and implement novel interventions for improving maternal and infant health. Since 2014 there have been a number of local efforts to address Franklin County's high rate of infant mortality to no avail. As such, there is a dire need for a coordinated novel multidisciplinary approach. The primary focus and intellectual contribution of this planning grant is to work closely with stakeholders to plan strategies to identify the key contributors of infant mortality in Franklin County (i.e., likely specific social determinants of health) and to develop novel interventions driven by innovations in BIGDATA technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the United States, there are concerning racial and ethnic disparities in maternal and infant health. The causes of these disparities are mutltfactorial and the use of technology holds promise for mitigating these vexing societal problems. The objectives of this work were two-fold: 1) to align with key stakeholders and to perform a gap analysis to identify barriers to optimal maternal and infant health, and 2) to formulate a plan to leverage content and technology expertise to design and implement novel interventions to improve maternal and infant health. 

Ohio has one of the highest rates of infant mortality in the US. Working with key stakeholders in Central Ohio we learned that efforts to address maternal and infant health remain somewhat disjointed. Various agencies attempt to address different social determinants of health and there is little care coordination among agencies, leaving mothers relying on multiple service providers operating in silos to obtain the support they need during pregnancy. For instance, while Medicaid managed care organizations provide transportation to physician appointments, they typically do not provide transportation to food banks or grocery stores. Given that stable access to healthy food is fundamental for maintaining good health, this leaves transportation insecure women with an important gap in services that could adversely impact their health and the health of their child(ren).

One key issue that has limited progress in the use of technology for improving maternal and infant health is the fact that prior to this work it was unknown if at-risk women have adequate access to technology. The women at highest risk of adverse maternal and infant health outcomes are those who are the most socioeconomically disadvantaged, leaving one to question whether a technological solution would be accessible to those who need it.

Indeed, we surveyed 100 women residing in neighborhoods in Central Ohio at highest risk of infant mortality and found that socioeconomically disadvantaged women have more access to technology than we anticipated. Ninety-four percent of women reported having access to a smart phone and 78% of women noted that their mobile phone plan had unlimited minutes. Very few women (4%) indicated that they typically run out of mobile phone minutes before the end of the month. Only one woman (1% of those surveyed) reported having no access to either a standard mobile phone, a smart phone, a computer, or a tablet. Among women who reported having a mobile phone or smartphone 87% reported that they had access to unlimited texting. Among that same group, 75% reported having an unlimited data plan. Only 2% of women reported that they did not have access to the internet. The most frequent sources of internet access included Wi-Fi at home (61%) and access on their phone over a cellular network (46%).

Our findings suggest that there is much room for improvement in the provision of seamless wrap-around services for women in the perinatal period. Technology has the potential to bridge these gaps in services and our data suggest that even the most socioeconomically disadvantaged women have the ability to access technological innovations aimed at providing more robust support during pregnancy and beyond.


Last Modified: 04/29/2020
Modified by: Raghu Machiraju
